00040 #ifndef actorcontainerbase_h
00041 #define actorcontainerbase_h
00042 
00043 #include "crossplatformexport.h"
00044 #include "actorbase.h"
00045 #include "world.h"
00046 
00047 namespace Ogre
00048 {
00049     class Node;
00050 }
00051 
00052 namespace phys
00053 {
00054 
00055 
00056     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00057     /// @class ActorContainerBase
00058     /// @headerfile actorcontainerbase.h
00059     /// @brief A base class to unify the interface for different kinds of containers for holding actors
00060     /// @details Containers for actors must implement atleast this interface(abstract base class) to
00061     /// be usable with the phys::World for tracking in game objects. There are several reasons why this
00062     /// will be useful. Our first thought was deriving from this and an STL container like vector or
00063     /// list. Members of this class should be implementing or inheriting a proper container\n\n
00064     /// The phys world will use one of these containers to store all of the actors for tracking purposes
00065     /// Since  \n\n
00066     /// In theory you should be be able to work with multiple actor containers and swiftly add or remove
00067     /// them to ad from a world to quickly control what actors are being worked with. It should even be
00068     /// possible to remove all actors, or have multiple set of actor in the world if you use the
00069     /// GameWorldSet methods carefully. \n\n
00070     /// Additionally the is no reason an actor could be in multiple containers so this can provide even
00071     /// more options for actor sorting and categorization at runtime. \n\n
00072     /// Because of this classes representation of a cursor only 1 thread at a time should use the cursor
00073     /// movement functions. For the container that the phys::World keeps it should be assume that the
00074     /// cursor is used. For other containers you should manage you container carefully and/or use another
00075     /// iteration method, such as STL iterators.
00076     class PHYS_LIB ActorContainerBase : public ManagerBase
00077     {
00078         protected:
00079             /// @internal
00080             /// @brief Used to work around the scenenode of an Actor being private, so all derived Containers can access it.
00081             Ogre::Node* GetNode(ActorBase* actor) const;
00082 
00083             /// @internal
00084             /// @brief Used to work around the collision object of an Actor being private, so all derived Containers can access it.
00085             btCollisionObject* GetCollisionObject(ActorBase* actor) const;
00086 
00087         public:
00088             /// @brief Basic Constructor
00089             /// @details This just assigned the passed pointer to ParentWorld
00090             ActorContainerBase();
00091 
00092             /// @brief Destructor
00093             /// @details This really doesn't do anything, but if someone needs to overload it, it's here
00094             virtual ~ActorContainerBase();
00095 
00096             /// @brief This will add an Actor to this container and the world
00097             /// @details This will add an Actor to this container and the world, and handle the nitty gritty details
00098             /// of add this to physics subsystem and graphics subsystem. \n\n
00099             /// This will not add the Actor to any specific location in the ordering of the container. \n\n
00100             /// It is expected that any container implementing this method will take appropriate steps to insure
00101             /// That the actor involved is added to the Physics and graphics world. This method could be called from
00102             /// derived to accomplish that task
00103             /// @param ActorToAdd This is a pointer to the actor to add.
00104             virtual void AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd);
00105 
00106             /// @brief This provides an easy way to access the last Actor added to this container
00107             /// @details For many containers this will simply return a pointer to the last actorl
00108             virtual ActorBase* LastActorAdded() = 0;
00109 
00110             /// @brief Remove an Actor
00111             /// @details Remove all references of the actor pointed from the container. Will throw an exception when attempting to remove
00112             /// and no match could be found.
00113             /// @warning This will cause issues if used with a container attached to a valid phys::World. Use World::RemoveActor instead.
00114             virtual void RemoveActor(ActorBase* ActorToRemove) = 0;
00115 
00116             /// @brief Removes the current actor
00117             /// @details This removes the actor the cursor at. Will throw an exception when attempting to remove from an empty container.
00118             /// Where the cursor goes is implementation dependent.
00119             /// @warning This will cause issues if used with a container attached to a valid phys::World. Use World::RemoveActor instead.
00120             virtual void RemoveActorAtCursor() = 0;
00121 
00122             /// @brief Returns how many actors this stores
00123             /// @return This returns a Whole number with the count of actors
00124             virtual Whole GetActorCount() const = 0;
00125 
00126             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the first item in the container
00127             /// @details This moves the cursor to the first item in the container change or return anything else.
00128             /// An exception will be throw if there are no valid items to move to with the cursor. There must be atleast one item to use any cursor
00129             /// moving functions.
00130             virtual void CursorToFirst() = 0;
00131 
00132             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the previous item in the container
00133             /// @details This moves the cursor to the previous item in the container, and if you started at the last item, you will
00134             /// visit every item in a properly implemented container, except for items that may have bee added during your traversal.
00135             /// It is also posible this could visit the same actor twice or more. When called from the first item this does nothing.
00136             /// An exception will be throw if there are no valid items to move to with the cursor. There must be atleast one item to use any cursor
00137             /// moving functions.
00138             virtual void CursorToPrevious() = 0;
00139 
00140             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the next item in the container
00141             /// @details This is the same as CursorToPrevious() except if you start from the begin you'll work your way to the end. If
00142             /// you are at the end, you'll stay their if you call this again
00143             virtual void CursorToNext() = 0;
00144 
00145             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the last item in the container
00146             /// @details This moves the cursor to the last item in the container change or return anything else. See CursorToFirst() for more details.
00147             virtual void CursorToLast() = 0;
00148 
00149             /// @brief This gets the actor at the cursor
00150             /// @details This gets the actor at the cursor, and will not move the cursor. If the cursor has not be set to a location, any valid
00151             /// actor in the container could be returned. Will throw an exception when attempting to get from an empty container.
00152             /// @return This returns a pointer to an ActorBase.
00153             virtual ActorBase* GetAtCursor() const = 0;
00154 
00155             /// @brief This gets the first actor in the container
00156             /// @details This and the actor the cursor points at after CursorToFirst() should match.
00157             /// @return This returns a pointer to an ActorBase. Will throw an exception when attempting to get from an empty container.
00158             virtual ActorBase* GetFirst() const = 0;
00159 
00160             /// @brief This gets the last actor in the container
00161             /// @details This and the actor the cursor points at after CursorToLast() should match.
00162             /// @return This returns a pointer to an ActorBase. Will throw an exception when attempting to get from an empty container.
00163             virtual ActorBase* GetLast() const = 0;
00164 
00165             /// @brief This finds an actor by searching for a graphics subsystem nodes
00166             /// @return This returns a pointer to and ActorBase that has a matching node
00167             /// @param GraphicsNode This is a pointer to a GraphicsNode that the Actor you want to find will have.
00168             virtual ActorBase* FindActor(Ogre::Node* GraphicsNode) = 0;
00169 
00170             /// @brief This finds an actor by searching for a physics subsystem object.
00171             /// @details This will iterate through each Actor in the container until it finds one with a matching physics object. This runs in linear time.
00172             /// @return This returns a pointer to and ActorBase that has a physics object.
00173             /// @param PhysicsObject This is a pointer to a physics object that the Actor you want to find will have.
00174             virtual ActorBase* FindActor(btCollisionObject* PhysicsObject) = 0;
00175 
00176             /// @brief This finds an actor based on its name
00177             /// @return This returns a pointer to and ActorBase that has a matching name
00178             /// @param Name This is the name of the Actor you want to find
00179             virtual ActorBase* FindActor(String Name) = 0;
00180 
00181             /// @brief Which kind of container it this anyway.
00182             /// @details Since this interface could be used with any type of containers and innumerable 3rd party container implemention this
00183             /// can be used to more safely cast this container to a more specific type.
00184             /// @return This returns a phys::String
00185             virtual String GetContainerType() const = 0;
00186 
00187             /// @brief This gets the World that this class is working with.
00188             /// @details This returns the gameworld that this container registers it's objects with. If this is not set, then this does not
00189             /// Register it's actors with any world.
00190             /// @return This returns a phys::World*
00191             virtual World* GetGameWorld() const = 0;
00192 
00193             /// @brief This sets the phys::World that this Manager works with.
00194             /// @details If the are any actors in the world, this removes them from both the physics and graphics subsystem, and adds them
00195             /// to the new world as is appropriate.
00196             /// @param GameWorld_ The new GameWorldPointer, or 0 to set none
00197             virtual void SetGameWorld( World* GameWorld_ ) = 0;
00198 
00199             /// @brief Optionally move actors into or out of a physworld
00200             /// @param GameWorld_ The new GameWorldPointer, or 0 to set none
00201             /// @param AddToWorld True to add AddActors if valid world pointer was supplied, false to not add
00202             /// @param RemoveFromWorld True to remove AddActors if valid world pointer was supplied, false to not remove
00203             virtual void SetGameWorld( World* GameWorld_, bool AddToWorld, bool RemoveFromWorld) = 0;
00204 
00205             /// @brief This returns the type of this manager.
00206             /// @return This returns ManagerTypeName::ActorContainerBase
00207             virtual ManagerTypeName GetType() const;
00208 
00209             // Inherited from ManagerBase
00210             virtual void Initialize() = 0;
00211             virtual void DoMainLoopItems() = 0;
00212 
00213     };
00214 }
00215 
00216 #endif
Generated on Fri Feb 11 2011 11:22:49 for PhysGameEngine by  1.7.1
